step: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil.
Cook the spaghetti according to the package instructions until al dente.
Reserve about 1 cup of pasta cooking water, then drain the spaghetti and set aside.
While the pasta is cooking, heat a large skillet over medium heat.
Reserve about 1 cup of pasta cooking water, then drain the spaghetti and set aside.
While the pasta is cooking, heat a large skillet over medium heat.
Add the diced pancetta or guanciale and cook until golden and crisp, about 5-7 minutes. Remove from the heat and set aside.
In a mixing bowl, whisk together the eggs, grated Pecorino Romano cheese, and grated Parmesan cheese until well combined.
Once the spaghetti is cooked and drained, immediately transfer it to the skillet with the cooked pancetta or guanciale.
Toss the spaghetti with the pancetta/guanciale and its rendered fat over low heat for about 1 minute, allowing the pasta to absorb some of the flavor.
Remove the skillet from the heat.
Quickly pour the egg and cheese mixture over the hot spaghetti while continuously tossing or stirring the pasta to evenly coat it with the sauce.
The residual heat from the pasta will cook the eggs and create a creamy sauce.
If the sauce seems too thick, gradually add some of the reserved pasta cooking water, a little at a time, until the desired consistency is reached.
Season the spaghetti carbonara generously with freshly ground black pepper.
Taste and adjust seasoning if necessary, keeping in mind that the pancetta or guanciale and cheeses are already salty.
Serve the spaghetti carbonara immediately, garnished with additional grated cheese and black pepper if desired.
Enjoy your delicious traditional Italian dish!
Arrange alternating slices of tomatoes and mozzarella cheese on a serving platter.
Tuck fresh basil leaves between the tomato and cheese slices.
Drizzle extra virgin olive oil over the salad.
Drizzle balsamic glaze over the top.
Season with salt and black pepper to taste.
Serve immediately as a refreshing appetizer or side dish.
Heat ghee or oil in a large pot.
Add sliced onions and cook until golden brown.
Remove half and set aside.
Add whole spices and ginger-garlic paste to the pot.
Cook until fragrant.
Add chicken pieces, yogurt, chopped tomatoes, potatoes, green chilies, and half of the chopped coriander and mint leaves.
Cook until chicken is partially cooked.
In a separate pot, boil water and cook soaked rice until partially done.
Drain and set aside.
Layer the partially cooked rice over the chicken mixture.
Sprinkle with remaining coriander and mint leaves, fried onions, and saffron-infused milk.
Cover and cook on low heat until the rice is fully cooked and the flavors are melded together.
Serve hot with raita.
In a skillet, melt butter over medium heat.
Add sliced beef and cook until browned.
Remove beef from skillet and set aside.
In the same skillet, add sliced onions and cook until translucent.
Add minced garlic and sliced mushrooms.
Cook until mushrooms are tender.
Sprinkle flour over the mushroom mixture and cook for 1-2 minutes.
Gradually pour in beef broth, stirring constantly to avoid lumps.
Bring to a simmer.
Return cooked beef to the skillet.
Stir in sour cream, Dijon mustard, and Worcestershire sauce.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Simmer gently for a few minutes until the sauce thickens and the beef is heated through.
Serve hot over cooked egg noodles or rice.
Garnish with chopped parsley.
